newsitem.title: FRANCE: Lagerfeld brings back Coco in Russia for Chanel.
newsitem.headline: Lagerfeld brings back Coco in Russia for Chanel.

text.p: German designer Karl Lagerfeld unveiled his autumn winter ready-to-wear collection for Chanel on Wednesday, with a return to the 1980s power look and a tribute to Coco Chanel's Slavic infatuation.

Lagerfeld resuscitated Coco Chanel's dalliance with Russia in Kandinsky motif embroidery on slim black evening wear, a blue coat with red Cossack embroidery and the pale, translucent make-up of flapper girls.
There were oversized wool coats for severe Russian winters and soft, cropped, nubby tweed jackets over wide boyish trousers that the grand old lady might have worn herself.
A hint of the gypsy showed in an occasional head scarf or wisps of sheer black that veiled darkly patterned velveteen or hung from dress hems.
Then he zoomed decades forward to sexy black or navy suits with the heavy shoulders of powerful women executives, short pleated skirts and stiletto high heels.

The show was about sleek lines and sombre colours, with few accessories, a far cry from the whimsical theatrics of British designers like John Galliano who unveiled his first collection for Dior on Tuesday, based on Shanghai nightclubs and bobby-socked baby dolls.

"We loved the shoes, the navy suits and the ethic embroidery touches, the cropped jackets with the boyish pants and the wonderful knitwear," said Nicole Fischlis of Saks Fifth Avenue. "The relaxed sportswear, the return of the big shoulder and the wider pants were great. There was a lot of classic, chic Chanel and very sleek cutting."

Dawn Mello, president of U.S. department store Bergdorf Goodman was more guarded. "It seemed to be a very eclectic collection. He represented both the soft and sporty clothes and also very strict tailoring in the suits and dresses. There was something for everyone," she said.
Power-dressing is starting to catch on in a big way this season.
Brazilian designer Ocimar Versolato showed it in his hard-edged, square-shouldered zip-up dresses that recall designer Claude Montana, one of the initiators of power dressing.
Hemlines, when they were not at the instep, were high on the thigh, especially on a fringed, single-sleeved black cocktail number and a bridal mini of lace petals.

But Versolato's forte is his evening wear, where he put to use his skilled hand at draping. That meant undulating black velvet skirts beneath off-the-shoulder knit bodices, or plum chiffon veiling a bubblegum pink satin brassiere and skirt.

He handled gazar fabric less deftly, submerging a model's head in one hooded pearl grey gown, but surmounted with finesse some technically difficult smocked chiffon columns in his intense and unusual palette of electric blue, aubergine, cocoa and claret.

"It was absolutely divine," said Maria Louisa, who owns a chain of shops. "I just loved, loved the zip dresses and absolutely adored the velvet and jersey gowns which are easy to wear without being overdressed. And I loved the smocking."
